Setting Up a New Cisco Switch

# Speed: 9600

item.title: Cisco Switch Hardening
item.description:
Cisco Switch Security Hardening

Comprehensive guide to hardening Cisco switches against attacks and unauthorized access.

Security Hardening Overview

Switch hardening involves multiple layers of security controls to protect against:

  • Unauthorized access - Physical and remote
  • Network attacks - VLAN hopping, MAC flooding, ARP spoofing
  • Layer 2 attacks - STP manipulation, DHCP starvation
  • Password attacks - Brute force, dictionary attacks
  • Denial of service - Resource exhaustion

Layer 1: Physical Security

Disable Unused Ports

! Disable and assign to parking VLAN
Switch(config)# vlan 999
Switch(config-vlan)# name PARKING_LOT
Switch(config-vlan)# exit

Switch(config)# interface range gigabitethernet 0/10-24
Switch(config-if-range)# description UNUSED - DISABLED
Switch(config-if-range)# switchport mode access
Switch(config-if-range)# switchport access vlan 999
Switch(config-if-range)# shutdown
Switch(config-if-range)# exit

item.title: Console Port Security
item.description:
Cisco Console Port Security

Comprehensive guide to securing console access on Cisco switches and routers.

Why Console Security Matters

The console port is often overlooked in security configurations, but represents a critical vulnerability:

  • Direct physical access bypasses most security controls
  • Password recovery can be performed via console
  • Full administrative access available once logged in
  • No network logging for some attack vectors

Basic Console Security

Set Console Password

Switch(config)# line console 0
Switch(config-line)# password ConsolePass123!
Switch(config-line)# login
Switch(config-line)# exit

Test: Disconnect and reconnect - should prompt for password.

item.title: Reconfiguring a Cisco Switch
item.description:
Reconfiguring a Cisco Switch from Scratch

How to completely reset and reconfigure a Cisco switch that has existing configuration.

Pre-Reconfiguration Checklist

Before wiping a switch, ensure:

  • You have console access
  • You’ve backed up the current configuration (if needed)
  • You understand the current network topology
  • You have authorization to reset the device
  • You have the new configuration ready

Option 1: Delete Configuration and Reload

Step 1: Backup Current Configuration (Optional)

Switch# show running-config
# Copy output to text file

# Or via TFTP
Switch# copy running-config tftp:
# Enter TFTP server IP and filename

Step 2: Erase Startup Configuration

Switch# write erase
Erasing the nvram filesystem will remove all configuration files! Continue? [confirm]
[OK]
Erase of nvram: complete

item.title: Remote Access Configuration
item.description:
Configuring Remote Access to Cisco Switches

Complete guide to setting up SSH and secure remote management access on Cisco switches.

Overview

Remote management allows you to configure and monitor switches without physical console access. This guide covers:

  • Assigning management IP addresses
  • Configuring SSH (recommended)
  • Securing remote access
  • Troubleshooting connectivity

Prerequisites

Before configuring remote access:

  • Console access to the switch
  • Network connectivity to the switch
  • IP address plan for management interface
  • DNS/hostname (required for SSH)

Assigning an IP Address to a Switch

Method 1: Using VLAN 1 (Default, Simple)

Switch# configure terminal

! Configure VLAN 1 interface
Switch(config)# interface vlan 1
Switch(config-if)# ip address 192.168.1.10 255.255.255.0
Switch(config-if)# no shutdown
Switch(config-if)# description Management Interface
Switch(config-if)# exit

! Set default gateway
Switch(config)# ip default-gateway 192.168.1.1

! Save configuration
Switch(config)# exit
Switch# write memory

Method 2: Using Dedicated Management VLAN (Best Practice)

! Create management VLAN
Switch(config)# vlan 99
Switch(config-vlan)# name MANAGEMENT
Switch(config-vlan)# exit

! Configure VLAN interface
Switch(config)# interface vlan 99
Switch(config-if)# ip address 192.168.99.10 255.255.255.0
Switch(config-if)# no shutdown
Switch(config-if)# description Management Interface
Switch(config-if)# exit

! Set default gateway
Switch(config)# ip default-gateway 192.168.99.1

! Assign a physical port to management VLAN (for connectivity)
Switch(config)# interface gigabitethernet 0/24
Switch(config-if)# switchport mode access
Switch(config-if)# switchport access vlan 99
Switch(config-if)# description Management Port
Switch(config-if)# exit

Verify IP Configuration

Switch# show ip interface brief
Interface IP-Address OK? Method Status Protocol
Vlan1 unassigned YES unset administratively down down
Vlan99 192.168.99.10 YES manual up up

! Test connectivity
Switch# ping 192.168.99.1

Configuring SSH Access

SSH provides encrypted remote access. Telnet is not recommended (unencrypted).

Cisco Switch VLAN Setup

Complete guide to creating, configuring, and managing VLANs on Cisco switches.

What is a VLAN?

A Virtual Local Area Network (VLAN) is a logical segmentation of a physical network:

  • Broadcast domain isolation - Traffic contained within VLAN
  • Security - Separate traffic between departments/functions
  • Performance - Reduce broadcast traffic
  • Flexibility - Group users by function, not physical location
